Award.AwardTitle: Stratigraphic Paleobiology and Historical Ecology of Po Basin
Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this project is the geologic history of Po River Delta (Adriatic Sea). Due to changes in sea level that took place over the last 125 thousand years, the Adriatic Sea first contracted and then expanded. Consequently, Po Delta migrated offshore by almost 300 km and then retreated back to its current location. This project will examine how these long-term changes impacted the delta. Documenting how coastal zones responded to past climate shifts is important because coastlines are particularly sensitive to current environmental changes. In the case of Po Plain, its diverse marine life is already in decline and its agricultural wealth is under threat. The local historical cities such as Venice are at risk as well. By using Po Delta as a model example for coastal responses to environmental changes, the project will also serve as a platform for K-12 activities, public outreach, and undergraduate and post-graduate training. The project will result in a public exhibit at the Florida Museum of Natural History and foster international partnership between University of Florida and University of Bologna.

A total of 112 sediment cores drilled under the Adriatic Sea will be used to reconstruct the geologic and ecologic history of Po Delta. The core sediment data will be used to describe the internal architecture of the delta. The cores should also produce ~1000 samples of marine fossils. In addition, geochemical methods will be employed to numerically date 400 mollusk specimens. Multivariate analyses and computer models will be applied to explore the resulting data. These analyses will allow for testing hypotheses regarding the development of river deltas under different climate regimes and long-term responses of marine ecosystems to environmental changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to changes in sea level that took place over the last two interglacial cycles (representing the past 125 thousand years), the Adriatic Sea first contracted and then expanded. Consequently, Italy’s Po River delta migrated offshore by almost 300 km and then subsequently returned to its current location. This award was used to conduct research on how these changes impacted the biological communities and sedimentary characteristics of the delta, information that advanced knowledge in the disciplines of paleontology, ecology, and geology.

Documenting how coastal zones responded to past climate shifts is important because coastlines are particularly sensitive to current environmental changes. In the case of Po Plain, its diverse marine life is already in decline, its agricultural wealth is under threat, and historical cities such as Venice are at risk. The project expanded on previous research of the Po Delta by looking at a broader geographic area over a longer interval of geologic time than had previously been done for this region.

The data came from samples of sediment under the Adriatic Sea, extracted by cores, which show the layers of sediment as they were deposited during changing sea levels. The core sediment also contained thousands of small marine fossils, primarily mollusk shells. Geochemical methods (radiocarbon dating) were used to date some of these fossils, and multivariate statistical analyses and computer models were applied to explore the resulting ecological and geological data. These analyses allowed for testing hypotheses regarding the development of river deltas under different climate regimes and long-term responses of marine ecosystems to environmental changes.

Key research findings from this project:

1. False extinction patterns can emerge simply as a result of local shifts in communities and non-random distribution of fossil-rich deposits, both controlled by sea-level changes. Our data allow better understanding of challenges and limitations involved in high-resolution reconstructions of past extinction dynamics, which is a crucial step before a deep-time perspective can be used as a baseline for evaluating the modern biodiversity crisis.

2. The resolution and quality of the paleontological data varies predictably along depositional profiles and across sea-level cycles. This highlights the importance of considering regional and sea-level contexts when interpreting paleontological and stratigraphic data.

3. Shifts in timing of local skeletal (shell) production rates can be reconstructed from the age-frequencies of fossil assemblages preserved in late Quaternary deposits from rising sea levels. This approach can be used to track responses of sea-floor species to episodes of abrupt climate change and sea-level rise following the Last Glacial Maximum, providing a model for predicting the impact of ongoing human-caused warming of coastal ecosystems.

4. Analysis of molluscan assemblages suggest that deltaic ecosystems of the Adriatic Sea have shifted back and forth between two ecosystem states, and responded with remarkable resilience to major, long-term shifts in climate and sea-level. This demonstration of resilient responses of deltaic communities to sea-level and climatic fluctuations has crucial implications for the understanding of long-term dynamics of marine ecosystems, and provides a baseline for assessing effects of recent anthropogenic impacts.

5. Reconstructed Holocene history of the fossil assemblages in the Po River Delta demonstrate close links between historical human-caused changes to the drainage basin, the geological development of the delta, and local marine biodiversity. The strongest change occurred in the last 800 years. Recognition of these long-term indirect effects of human actions may improve conservation and management of coastal ecosystems.

6. Parasitism on bivalve hosts increased with high sea level events in the late Holocene, which highlights the importance of deep-time data for understanding the potential impact of global changes on ecosystems, ecosystem services, and environmental and human health. This outcome provides important insights regarding future threats to ecosystems that may result from the current warming and sea-level rise.

7. Finally, our research on the Po Delta shows that the best way to study ecological patterns of the past is to consider fossils, patterns in the layers of sediment, and environmental context together. This joint consideration improves our ability to interpret past ecosystems. 

These research findings were shared in scientific journals, conferences, and as learning activities for students, as well as in other formats accessible to both the scientific community and the general public. The project supported and trained multiple undergraduate student interns, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers. The mollusk data resulting from this project are available to other researchers in multiple forms, including as curated collections at the Florida Museum in Gainesville, Florida, as well as on our project website where we provide links to the archived datasets.
